snippet: Scientists say a pair of supermassive black holes appear to be spiraling toward a galaxy-wrecking collision that could release as much energy as 100 million supernova explosions.
abstract: Astronomers reporting in journal Nature say two supermassive black holes in galaxy about 3.5 billion light years away seem to be heading toward collision that could release energy equal to 100 million supernova explosions and destroy galaxy; event gives preview of what will happen when Andromeda galaxy collides with Milky Way galaxy in several billion years, as they both contain huge black holes.
lead_paragraph: Scientists say a pair of supermassive black holes appear to be spiraling toward a galaxy-wrecking collision that could release as much energy as 100 million supernova explosions.

headline.main: Black Holes Inch Ahead to Violent Cosmic Union
headline.print_headline: Black Holes Inch Ahead to Violent Cosmic Union
